author: gabloe
body:
From documentation I see that Write-Host does not pollute any output stream and instead gets written directly to the console.  But, it seems that is not the case when I use *> to redirect all streams.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
> $(write-host "foo"; write-output "bar") *> foobar.txt
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```powershell
> gc foobar.txt
bar
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```powershell
> gc foobar.txt
foo
bar
```

Environment data
----------------

comments.author: PetSerAl
comments.body: Starting from v5, `Write-Host` is mostly a wrapper for `Write-Information`, which "pollute" new information (6) stream.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
You can read about the enhancement in https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/reference/5.0/microsoft.powershell.utility/write-information 
>Starting in Windows PowerShell 5.0, Write-Host is a wrapper for Write-Information. You can now use Write-Host to emit output to the information stream, but the $InformationPreference preference variable and InformationAction common parameter do not affect Write-Host messages. Information streams also work for PowerShell.Streams, jobs, scheduled jobs, and workflows.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@gabloe:

If you still need something that bypasses PowerShell's streams (which is generally to be avoided), you can use `$Host.UI.WriteLine()`.

title: Stream redirection also picks up host messages when using *>
